course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Signal Processing and Communications
course.description: The course provides a comprehensive overview of signal processing and communications using quantitative modeling and analysis. Topics include: 7 layer communications model, discrete Fourier transform and z-transform, IIR and FIR filter design techniques and realizations, complexity and implementation considerations of FFT and FIR/IIR, source coding, digital modulation, PSD and spectrum, effects of noise to communication system designs, detection theory, matched filter, signal space and error analysis, channel models and channel coding. Application examples are provided to illustrate on how practical communication systems are designed using these quantitative tools. Design projects are set up so that the students can apply theory learnt in the class to physical problems. MATLAB CAD tools are being used as an integral part of this course.
course.prerequisites: (ELEC 2100 OR ELEC 2100H) AND (ELEC 2600 OR ELEC 2600H)

reviews.author: syrus
reviews.title: MY too op
reviews.comment_content:
If you don't want to watch the desciption, skip it. But the things after the "" mark is my opinion. You can check.
By the course description,
"This course provides a broad treatment of signal processing and communications: discrete time signal and system, filter design, source coding, channel coding, digital modulation theory, channel model, and noise effects.

The objective is to comprehend the basic theory about signal processing including discrete-time signals and systems, and filter design; and have a basic understanding of communications systems including source coding, channel coding, digital modulation, detection theory, and error analysis.

MATLAB CAD tools are being used as an integral part of this course."

Actually, it is the advanced knowledge of ELEC2100. It is relatively easy if you understand the content of ELEC2100. If you don't understand it, don't worry. The content of ELEC3100 is easier than ELEC2100, unless the last 1-2 chapters.
reviews.comment_teaching:
You can skip the lectures but I don't recommend it as Daniel will sometimes demonstrate the calculation or derivation behind some of the concepts.

Never skip the tutorials! MY can make the concepts of the contents clearer and if you really don't understand, feel free to ask her! Also she will give some hints for your homework and labs
reviews.comment_grading: Almost full mark for the lab, assignment about 60%, got mean in midterm and final. Finally I got a B+. Thanks MY.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 assignments, 5 labs.
Assignments are MY's level. That means not so many sources you can find for the questions. Try to do the homeworks by yourself. They are really helpful for preparing your final and midterm. there will be pre-lab for the 5 labs. If you have installed Matlab in your laptop, you can just write the code before you go to the lab, then demonstrate the code. That saves lots of your time

reviews.author: sytz
reviews.comment_content:
1. Overview of Signal Processing and Communication Systems
2. Discrete-Time Signals
3. Frequency Analysis for DT Signals & Systems
    - DTFT for DT Signals & Systems
    - DFT
    - FFT
    - Z Transformation
4. FIR Filter Design
5. Source Coding
6. Channel Coding
7. Baseband Communications & Noise
----------------------------------------------------
(Not in Final's range)
8. Wireless Channel Models
9. Multiplexing and Multiple Access
reviews.comment_teaching:
Takes attendance through canvas quiz. Just typing in the password given by professor in class.  
Professor Lau is very knowledgeable in this field and gives very detailed explanation about the course. I would recommend not to skip any of his classes. He answers any questions after class. He also gives Midterm revision.

I cannot understand the TA's English. My bad.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm 30%
Final 45%
Lab 10%
HW 15%
Not taking one of the labs or taking less than 80% of lectures will get F.
reviews.comment_workload:
4 labs 3 assignment
Assignments are long and difficult but essential for learning the concepts. Better do assignment in group. The class had a telegram group to discuss. ELEC 2100 materials also help a lot in writing assignments.

Labs are MATLAB-based. They are difficult and cannot be finished in time if not previewing before time, especially the last 2 labs. TA will teach how to do the questions during lab tho.

No project and presentation.

reviews.author: rubbishChing
reviews.comment_content:
First half of the semester is a difficult version of ELEC2100 where you learn about Fourier transform, z-transform and DFT/FFT. If you understand ELEC2100 well then you won't have great problems here.
The next half of the semester teaches filters and how noise reacts with filters, and the mathematics behind creating the optimum filter.
Knowledge about MATLAB definitely helps understanding the content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
MY teaches everything important in her tutorials. She makes every concept clear. She might sound mean when you ask her questions, but she will make sure you understand your problem. She will also give hints to homework and lab!
Prof Palomar is sometimes interesting in class. He not only talks about course content, and also talks about how the technology was used in history. If you like to learn additional stuff, it is better to attend the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: Almost full marks in lab, 80% in homework, above 1.5sd for midterm, above 0.6sd for final: got A
reviews.comment_workload:
There are lab every 1-2 weeks. It lasts for 1 hour only, but might sometimes overrun for half hour. You need to do prelab otherwise you can't finish the lab.
3 homework for the whole semester. Most concepts used in the questions are explained in lecture or in tutorial, so if you attend them all, it is relatively easier. Plus if you are stuck, you can always ask MY!

reviews.author: tttts
reviews.title: Interesing Course
reviews.comment_content:
Lecture Topics

Introduction and Discrete‐Time Signals
Discrete‐Time Systems and DTFT for DT Signals and Systems
Discrete Fourier Transform
Fast Fourier Transform and z‐Transform
z‐Transform
FIR Filter Design and Digital Filter and Source Coding
Source Coding
Channel Coding
Baseband Communications and Noise and Optimal Receiver
Optimal Receiver and Digital Modulation
Digital Modulation and Signal Space
Signal Space
Channel Models and Multiplexing and Multiple Access


Laboratory Topics

CT and DT signals
Introduction to DFT
Convolution and Filter
Information theory
BER simulation


Key References

(1) Sanjit K. Mitra, “Digital Signal Processing”, McGraw‐Hill, 4th Ed., 2011.

(2) John G. Proakis, "Digital Communications", 5th Ed., 2008.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. ZHANG explains the knowledge patiently and in detail. He would write many notes on the ppt during the lecture and update the annotaed version to canvas after every class. It's would be extremely helpful to make up the missing class or to do the revision before the exam.

All the TAs are quite responsible and willing to answer the questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
HW:15%=5%*2(Mean：~70/100， mine : ~99/100)
Lab:10%=2.5%*4(Mean~30/40, mine:~39.5/40)
Midterm: 30%(Mean: 65, mine: 92(high:92))
Final: 45%(Mean:61, mine:81(high:97))

Final grade: A+
I didn't expect to get an A+ since the final weighs 45% but it was kind of tricky and my score was far away from high. But thanks to the prof. ZHANG's kind grading scheme!
reviews.comment_workload:
Kind of heavy actually to fully understand all the knowledge in the course.
Also, there seems to be  only a few labs and hws but each of them is quite time-consuming. But try to do all the labs and hws and figure out any knowledge points that you're confused with, it'll be a great help to the exam.
And I have to mention that the lab needs an attendance or you won't get any points even you submit a perfect report.

reviews.author: 落車請早揚聲
reviews.title: Looks like there aren't enough review for Vincent's 3100...
reviews.comment_content:
This is basically a continue version of ELEC2100.

Listed content:
Chap1. Overview of Signal Processing and Communication Systems
Chap2. Discrete-Time Signals
Chap3. Frequency Analysis for DT Signals & Systems
    - DTFT for DT Signals & Systems
    - DFT
    - FFT
    - Z Transformation
Chap4. FIR Filter Design
Chap5. Source Coding
Chap6. Channel Coding
Chap7. Baseband Communications & Noise

Among them, chap 1,2 and the DTFT part of Chap 3 you can almost just rely on knowledge from ELEC2100. The only new thing was signal correlation as far as I recall. Starting from DFT is new content.
For me, Z-transform, FIR Filter Design and Chap7 was the most complicated part. Especially Chap7 which requires really decent knowledge in random process.
The last question in the final exam was actually an "INNOVATIVE" question set up on the background of chap7, and it was pretty damn difficult.

The content was overall less decent than I imagined though.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof LAU's teaching is pretty good. He elaborates a lot on certain derivations and really emphasizes understanding. I wished I attended more lessons but 9 am was really quite a big problem for me :<

The TA SIM Yi hang is absolutely amazing. He holds absolutely perfect English accent in almost native speaker level, and the content in the tutorial's are also very helpful for the homework and exams. (I suspect that proabably he is the guy designing those exam questions)
He responds very quickly to emails, and he is also very lenient in marking the exam papers, he literally gives as much point as he could based on you derivation even if your final answer is wrong. Really a kind and helpful guy. Btw, I found he was an undergrad in hkust as well and that he was a "academic achievement medal" awardee in 2021, which means he had a cga more tha 3.9 upon graduation in HKUST. Yikes....
reviews.comment_grading:
the grading scheme is as follows:
midterm 30%
final 45%
lab 10% (four labs in total)
hw 15% (three hws in total)

The grading was probably very lenient (due to the lenient grading by the TA I suppose XD, so the prof was more willing to give more As.)
And in deed most students scored very well in both exams. The distribution of both exams are attached.

Here are some scores from me and my friends:
hw and labs almost full, midtem 95/100, final 89/100
hw and labs almost full, midterm 90/100, final 92/100
hw and labs almost full, midterm 92/100, final 91/100
hw and labs almost full, midterm 92/100, final 88/100
And we all got A+

Do check answers with friends for the hw and labs (not to copy) if you want to secure that 25% of grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload started pretty low, since plenty of content are from elec2100. But starting from hw1 the workload gradually increases. HW1 was very lengthy and time consuming. HW2 was slightly better but still takes quite a while to work on. The same due date of HW2 was the midterm exam. So those few weeks were very tight. After that, the workload drops again because source coding and channel coding are relatively easier topics, and the workload booms up again when it comes to chap7 and hw3 was released.

reviews.author: gdhdsv
reviews.comment_content:
Basic digital signal processing.
ch1 introduction to the course
ch2 DT signals, system, sampling process, convolution
ch3 DTFT, DFT, FFT, z transform
ch4 filter design
ch5 source coding
ch6 channel coding
ch7 baseband communication

Easy stuff before ch6.
ch1 to ch4 is just a deeper version of elec 2100.
ch5 maybe is quite new for someone, but not hard to understand. It is about lossy source coding like PCM and lossless coding like huffman, arithmetic encoing and LZW algorithm.
ch6 is just deeper version of elec 1200 hamming code part except the reed solomon coding.
ch7 is a harder and more general version of elec 1200 bit error rate calculation.

Things become harder to understand in ch6 reed solomon code and ch7 baseband communication.

Therefore this course is a very easy good grade course for those who did very well in elec1200 and elec2100 (A range in both course). As long as you understand the easy stuff very well, it will be enough to get A. ELEC2600 only helps you in the last chapter, ch7 and the first part of ch5.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Lau is knowledgeable about signal processing and has great math sense. He teaches well and always elaborate the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
4 lab 15% I got 13.406%
3 hw 10% I got 9.375%
1 midterm 30% mean is 74.6/100 I got 86
1 final 45% mean is 65.5/100 I got 78

overall I got 83.7%
I got A

Although I messed up the last question about ch7 in final(I think many people messed up), I can still get high marks by finishing easy questions.

Overall very easy good grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is low

3 assignments in total, 4 matlab labs per 2 weeks.

Just like elec2100

reviews.author: Keegan
reviews.title: Very good course
reviews.comment_content: Very interesting content about Fourier analysis and other frequency-based transforms. The later part of the course covers wireless communication, covering modulation, channels, and signal space.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very interesting and helpful instructor. Frequently makes jokes and analogies, and generally enjoyable to watch.

Tutorials are helpful as well, where MY goes through important concepts and demonstrates how to solve important problems.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair grading. There are labs (just a few of them) which are required. There is a MATLAB-based quiz, but counts for little and is not too difficult with some practice. Midterm and final make up most of the grade are challenging but very doable.
reviews.comment_workload: Homework is difficult and long. However, it is necessary to understand the concepts and greatly enhances learning. There is also ample support provided should get stuck on a problem. Very little work other than that, without group projects or essays.

reviews.author: Bamboo
reviews.comment_content:
Not easy to understand !! Find material for yourself

The course provides a comprehensive overview of signal processing and communications using quantitative modeling and analysis. Topics include: 7 layer communications model, discrete Fourier transform and z-transform, IIR and FIR filter design techniques and realizations, complexity and implementation considerations of FFT and FIR/IIR, source coding, digital modulation, PSD and spectrum, effects of noise to communication system designs, detection theory, matched filter, signal space and error analysis, channel models and channel coding. Application examples are provided to illustrate on how practical communication systems are designed using these quantitative tools. Design projects are set up so that the students can apply theory learnt in the class to physical problems. MATLAB CAD tools are being used as an integral part of this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Daniel talks very fast, so you must pay attention of course. The TA MY could be even faster than Daniel.

Yet MY can help you to clear concept efficiently. In short, don't skip lecture and tutorial.
reviews.comment_grading:
No pain no gain, normal grade.
No pain no gain, normal grade.
No pain no gain, normal grade.
No pain no gain, normal grade.
No pain no gain, normal grade.
No pain no gain, normal grade.

Declare, I got A- Yeah
reviews.comment_workload: Few homework, suggested to do it by yourself for study. It really helps.

reviews.title: good grade course!
